text: 5.2 Beef production around the world Stuart Barber Associate Professor srbarber@unimelb.edu.au VETS30030 / VETS90123 World wide beef production • Australia has a relatively small percentage of the international beef cattle herd – about 2% (2019 data) • It is however a prominent exporter, in 2019 ranked second behind Brazil on kilograms shipped • Exported 76% of beef produced • Australia also exported 1.3 million head of live cattle worth 1.6billion AUD, mostly to Indonesia and Vietnam Beef exports note 1,000 difference in graphic, live export mostly <400kg bodyweight, %carcass weight generally 50%-60% Market change over time • Some markets considered premium (eg Japan), others commodity market (e.g. Indonesia) – different pricing for the different markets • Most Australian beef to Indonesia is in live cattle sales for fattening Changes in worldwide beef production • Limited scope across world to increase beef production • Relative pricing between livestock/crops can change • Minimal extra available land • Opportunity to intensify in some areas • Cyclical nature of beef markets (see USA example below left) • Long gestation and growth part of this, plus environment, plus competition • Increased production in Arica, S America and Asia https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/animal-products/cattle-beef/sector-at-a- glance/ Dairy genetics in the beef market • Varying percentage of dairy genetics in beef production systems around the world • Australia has relatively low % • Dairy cows have less muscle Beef prices in markets • Beef pricing varies depending on quality of individual part of carcass but overall animal quality • Quality assurance (QA) important – reliability, safety
